title: How to Cut, Deseed, and Eat a Pomegranate

steps.title: Cut off the top of the pomegranate with a sharp knife.
steps.content: Cut off the top of the pomegranate with a sharp knife. The top of the pomegranate has the pointed blossom end. [1] X Expert Source Ollie George Cigliano Private Chef & Food Educator Expert Interview. 31 January 2022. Set the fruit on its side and slice through the top of the pomegranate to expose the membrane and seeds inside. [2] X Research source Rinse the pomegranate under running water to get rid of any dirt and debris on the surface. [3] X Research source Throw the top of the pomegranate away. While the rind is edible, it’s really bitter and not as flavorful as the seeds.

steps.title: Score vertical lines in the pomegranate’s rind along the section lines.
steps.content: Score vertical lines in the pomegranate’s rind along the section lines. If you look where you just cut, you’ll see ridges separating the sections of seeds inside the fruit. [4] X Research source Place your knife on the pomegranate’s skin and make a straight line down to the bottom of the fruit. Be careful not to cut all the way through the fruit. Make a cut wherever you see a ridge inside the pomegranate. [5] X Expert Source Ollie George Cigliano Private Chef & Food Educator Expert Interview. 31 January 2022. Cutting through the fruit could damage some of the seeds, but scoring the skin makes it easier to pull apart on your own.

steps.title: Submerge the pomegranate in a bowl of cold water.
steps.content: Submerge the pomegranate in a bowl of cold water. Since the seeds sink and the inedible parts of the pomegranate float, water makes them easier to collect. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the sections apart by hand.
steps.content: Pull the sections apart by hand. Push your thumbs into the middle of the cut that you made on top of the pomegranate. Apply a little bit of pressure so the pomegranate splits into sections and exposes all of the red seeds, or arils, inside. The score marks make it easier for the rind to split without breaking any of the seeds.

steps.title: Push the seeds out from the rind using your fingers.
steps.content: Push the seeds out from the rind using your fingers. Work on one section of pomegranate at a time. Keep the pomegranate underwater as you slide your fingers along the rind. The white membrane will float to the top and easily separate from the seeds. [7] X Research source Pick the white membrane out of the bowl and throw it away. If you have trouble getting the seeds out by hand, try scooping them out with a spoon. You may even be able to tap the back of the rind with a spoon so the loose seeds fall out.

steps.title: Strain the seeds with a colander.
steps.content: Strain the seeds with a colander. After you finish seeding all of the pomegranate sections, pour the bowl into a colander to catch all of the seeds. Shake any excess water from the seeds and pick out any membrane that’s still stuck to them so they’re ready to use! [8] X Research source

steps.title: Eat the pomegranate seeds by themselves for a sweet snack.
steps.content: Eat the pomegranate seeds by themselves for a sweet snack. As soon as you separate them from the rind, you can eat pomegranate seeds by the spoonful just like a bowl of cereal. The seeds are filled with juice and have a little crunch so they make a perfect snack whenever you’re hungry. [9] X Research source The whole seed is safe to eat, but you can spit it out after eating the juicy red part surrounding it if you prefer.

steps.title: Top a parfait or oatmeal with pomegranate seeds to add some crunch.
steps.content: Top a parfait or oatmeal with pomegranate seeds to add some crunch. Pomegranates are super nutritious and they make a great addition to a balanced breakfast. Sprinkle the fresh seeds on top and mix them in so you can have a burst of flavor in every bite. [10] X Research source Try adding pomegranate seeds into your breakfast cereal. Mix the pomegranate into a fruit bowl to add even more nutrients.

steps.title: Sprinkle pomegranate seeds on a salad for a pop of color.
steps.content: Sprinkle pomegranate seeds on a salad for a pop of color. Pomegranate seeds give any salad a bit of sweetness and tartness, so sprinkle a few on before you dig in. Try the pomegranate on a spinach salad with nuts and feta or in a chicken salad with celery and almonds. Make a fruit salad with pomegranate, apples, mango, and any other fruit you want to enjoy.

steps.title: Garnish your entrees with pomegranate seeds for fresh flavors.
steps.content: Garnish your entrees with pomegranate seeds for fresh flavors. Combine the sweet flavor of the pomegranate seeds with the savory meal to add a lot of depth to the flavor. Try sprinkling the pomegranate seeds on meatballs, pork chops, or an herbal flatbread. [11] X Research source Always add the pomegranate seeds after you cook your meal so they stay nice and juicy.

steps.title: Spice up your desserts with pomegranate seeds.
steps.content: Spice up your desserts with pomegranate seeds. Since pomegranate seeds add a sweet flavor and a crunchy texture, they pair really well with any type of dessert. Try out your pomegranate on top of a cake or fruit pie. You could even mix the seeds into a pudding or cheesecake to make them the star of your dessert. [12] X Research source Sprinkle some pomegranate onto ice cream for a classic berries-and-cream flavor.

steps.title: Juice the pomegranate seeds
steps.content: Juice the pomegranate seeds to enjoy a sweet, tart drink. Just put the seeds in a citrus squeezer or use a masher to get all the juices out of the seeds. Juice the seeds over a large bowl or glass so it doesn’t splatter. Once you have enough in your cup, drink it fresh or use it in another recipe. [13] X Research source Try adding the pomegranate juice to club soda or punch to make it even more flavorful. Mix the juice with red wine vinegar and olive oil to make a vinaigrette. [14] X Research source
